questions.question: Based on the properties of viruses, which of the following sentences is not true?

options.A: A virus can either possess DNA or RNA, but never both.
options.B: All animal viruses are spherical in shape.
options.C: Viruses are obligate intracellular and can only replicate inside a host cell.
options.D: All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) All animal viruses are spherical in shape Explanation: Animal viruses have different shapes, but most are spherical. General properties of viruses Characteristics They do not have a cellular organisation. Obligate intracellular parasites - cannot replicate outside a host. (Option C) Lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis. Multiply via a complex process. They cannot be cultured in cell-free culture media but can grow in embryonated eggs or tissue culture. They can pass through filters. Morphology All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material. Either possess DNA or RNA but never both. (Option A) Nucleic acid is enclosed by a protein capsid, which may or may not be enclosed by a lipid envelope. (Option D) Shape Most are spherical. (Option B) Some are irregular and pleomorphic Different shapes of animal viruses are Rabies virus - bullet-shaped Ebola virus - filamentous Pox virus - brick shaped Tobacco mosaic virus - rod-shaped Size Ranges from 300 nm - Poxvirus to 20 nm - Parvovirus Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 433 Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 80

questions.question: Based on the image given below, which of the following statements is true regarding the symmetry of the viruses? Poxvirus has a symmetry similar to structure A Adenovirus has a symmetry similar to structure B Rhabdovirus has a symmetry similar to structure A Structure B has two types of capsomers The helical tube in structure A is rigid in all viruses with a similar structure.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: The symmetry of the virus depends on the arrangement of the capsomers surrounding the nucleic acid. Symmetry of virus Icosahedral Helical Complex Polygon with 12 vertices and 20 sides Consist of two types of capsomer (Statement 4) Structure is rigid All DNA viruses have this symmetry except for Poxvirus Eg Adenovirus (Statement 2) Herpesvirus Hepadnavirus Papovavirus Capsomers are coiled around the nucleic acid in the form of a spiral or helix. The tube is rigid in tobacco mosaic virus but flexible in animal virus (Statement 5) Seen in a few RNA viruses Eg Myxoviruses Rhabdovirus (Statement 3) Filovirus Complex symmetry is seen in a few viruses, such as Poxvirus (Statement 1)

questions.question: A 34-year-old researcher accidentally exposes a viral sample to alcohol during a lab procedure. He recalls that alcohol can disrupt certain viral structures. Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure of viral envelopes and capsids?

options.A: Hemagglutinin is a protein subunit found exclusively in non-enveloped viruses.
options.B: Non-enveloped viruses are more alcohol labile than enveloped viruses.
options.C: Viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane.
options.D: Capsid in enveloped viruses gives the virus its pleomorphic shape.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane. virus is released by budding. STRUCTURE OF VIRUS CAPSID : Protein coat surrounding the viral nucleic acid. It is composed of small morphological units called capsomeres The polypeptide molecules are arranged symmetrically It forms an impenetrable shell around the nucleic core It is adsorbed by the host cell membrane readily, thus introducing the viral genome into the host ENVELOPED: Viral capsid is surrounded by a lipid membrane It is derived from the host cell membrane by viral progeny during the budding process (Option C) They have protein subunits that project on the envelope surface ( Peplomers ), which are viral-coded The shape of the virus depends on the lipid envelope. (Option D) Example (Option A) Influenza virus has two types of peplomers: Hemagglutinin : Triangular spike. Neuraminidase : Mushroom-shaped structure. Functions: Confers chemical , antigenic , and biological properties . Facilitates attachment to host cell surfaces. Aids in processes such as hemagglutination Enveloped viruses are sensitive to lipid solvents, including Ether, Chloroform and Bile salts. Specific neutralisation of virus infectivity is mediated by antibodies targeting surface antigens. Some viruses may have unique structural features, e.g., fibrils protruding from the vertices of adenovirus particles. NON-ENVELOPED: Lack the lipid membrane, and viral capsid is naked They lack the lipid membrane More resistant to lipid solvents (Option B) The shape of the virus depends on the shape of the capsid (Option D) Most viruses are enveloped except: Naked DNA viruses: Parvovirus, Papavovirus and Adenovirus Naked RNA viruses: Picornaviruses, reovirus, calicivirus, astroviridae, Hep A and Hep E Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 435. Sensitivity Evaluation of Enveloped and Non-enveloped Viruses to Ethanol Structure and Classification of Viruses - Medical Microbiology

questions.question: Three patients come to the hospital, each presenting with three different infectious diseases. Patient A has Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Patient B has Potato spindle tuber viroid disease. Patient C has an Influenza type B infection. Which option correctly describes the composition of each pathogen? Enveloped RNA without a capsid

options.A: Patient A: Nucleic acids only Patient B: Protein and nucleic acids Patient C: RNA only
options.B: Patient A: Infectious protein only Patient B: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid Patient C:
options.C: Patient A: Enveloped RNA Patient B: Infectious protein only Patient C: Naked circular ssRNA
options.D: Patient A: Enveloped RNA Patient B: RNA only Patient C: Protein and nucleic acids

questions.explanation: capsid Patient C: Enveloped RNA Correct Answer: B) Patient A: Infectious protein only; Patient B: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid; Patient C: Enveloped RNA Explanation: Patient A (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease ) is caused by a prion, an infectious protein . Patient B (Potato spindle tuber viroid) involves a viroid, a naked circular ssRNA without a capsid. Patient C (Influenza type B) involves an enveloped RNA virus. VIRUS VIROID PRION Definition Infectious agent composed of nucleic acid enclosed in a protein coat with or without a lipid envelope. (Patient C) Infectious molecule composed of small, circular ssRNA without a capsid. (Patient B) Infectious agent, composed of only infectious proteins. (Patient A) Composition DNA/RNA + protein +/- Lipid. RNA only. Protein only. Replication Replicates using host cellular machinery Replicates using host cellular machinery. Replicates by inducing protein misfolding in the host. Stability Stability varies Enveloped viruses are sensitive to lipid solvents, while non-enveloped are more resistant. Resistant to heat and organic solvent. Resistant to heat and proteolytic enzymes and heat, it can remain infectious for years. Examples Influenza virus, Poxvirus, Reovirus Potato spindle tuber viroid, Plant diseases Creutzfeldt-jakob disease Virion: Complete virus particle that includes a genome and a protein coat, which exists outside of host cells, representing one of the physical forms of a virus during a specific phase of its replication cycle. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 448 Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 81 Virion Structure and Composition - PMC

questions.question: Identify the mismatched pair of viruses and their site of viral replication. Adenovirus - Cytosol Poxvirus - Cytosol Parvovirus - Nucleus HIV - Mixed
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Adenovirus - Cytosol Explanation: Adenovirus - Cytosol is a mismatched pair because adenovirus is a DNA virus that replicates in the nucleus, similar to most DNA viruses. Most DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus of the host cells, with a few exceptions, such as poxvirus, which replicates in the cytosol (Option A) . Examples of DNA viruses: Hepadna virus, Reovirus, Parvovirus (Option C) , Adenovirus (Option B) and Papovavirus Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytosol of the host cells except for orthomyxovirus and retroviruses(HIV) (Option D) , which synthesise their RNA in the nucleus. Reference: Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 83

questions.question: Based on the steps of viral replication, label the following diagram

options.A: A - Attachment, B - Translation, C- Transcription, D- budding
options.B: A - Penetration, B - Translation, C- Transcription, D- budding
options.C: A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation
options.D: A - Attachment, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D- Maturation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation Explanation: The above diagram shows the steps of viral replication within the host cell, and the labelling is A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation. VIRAL REPLICATION Attachment : Receptor interaction between viral surface antigen and host cell surface antigens. HIV: Viral surface gp120 binds to CD 24 on host cells. Influenza: Viral hemagglutinin binds to glycoprotein receptors on respiratory epithelium Penetration: Viral particle enters the host cells via - Phagocytosis/viropexis (receptor mediated endocytosis occurs) Membrane fusion (some enveloped viruses enter via fusion of their membrane with the host cell membrane; thus, only the nucleocapsid enters). Injection of nucleic acid by bacteriophages. Uncoating: Host cell lysosomal enzymes separate the viral capsid and nucleic acid. Biosynthesis Nucleic acid replication DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus except for the Pox virus, which replicates in the cytosol. RNA viruses replicate within the cytosol except retroviruses and orthomyxoviruses Transcription of Viral nucleic material DNA viruses: DNA is transcribed into RNA in the mRNA in the cytosol. + sense RNA viruses: Directly replicated/transcribed or translated - sense RNA viruses: Transcribed into +ve sense RNA first, which is then replicated dsRNA viruses +ve strand is directly replicated/transcribed or translated. -ve strand is transcribed into +ve sense RNA first. Both strands can serve as templates for complementary strands In retroviruses, reverse transcription converts viral single-stranded RNA

questions.question: A virology lab receives samples from a patient with a suspected viral infection presenting with fever, cough, and body aches. Testing confirms the presence of an RNA virus. Which of the following is an example of an RNA virus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Respiratory syncytial virus Explanation: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is an RNA virus. Epstein-Barr virus , JC virus , and Adenovirus are DNA viruses . DNA virus RNA virus Herpesviridae: Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1, HSV-2) Varicella-zoster virus Epstein-Barr virus (Option A) Cytomegalovirus (CMV) HHV-6,7,8 Hepadnaviridae: Hepatitis B virus Parvoviridae: Parvovirus B19 Papovaviridae: Human papillomavirus (HPV) JC virus (Option B) BK virus Poxviridae: Variola virus (smallpox) Molluscum contagiosum virus Adenoviridae: Human adenovirus (Option C) Bacteriophage Picornaviridae: Poliovirus Coxsackievirus Rhinovirus Hepatitis A virus Enterovirus Caliciviridae: Hepatitis E virus Togaviridae: Rubella virus Eastern equine encephalitis virus Western equine encephalitis virus Flaviviridae: Yellow fever virus Dengue virus Hepatitis C virus West Nile virus Coronaviridae: SARS-CoV MERS-CoV SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) Rhabdoviridae: Rabies virus Filoviridae: Ebola virus Paramyxoviridae: Measles virus Mumps virus Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) Nipah virus Parainfluenza virus Orthomyxoviridae: Influenza viruses (A, B, C, D) Bunyaviridae Arenaviridae Reoviridae: Rotavirus Reovirus Colorado tick fever virus Retroviridae: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) Human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) Types of RNA Viruses: Positive-sense RNA Viruses have genomes that can be directly translated into proteins by the host cell's ribosomes. Negative-Sense RNA Viruses have genomes that cannot be directly translated into proteins. Instead, their RNA must first be converted into a complementary positive-sense RNA by an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase before translation can occur.

questions.question: Which of the following non-enveloped viruses contain DNA as their genetic material?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Papovavirus Explanation Papovavirus is a non-enveloped virus that contains DNA as its genetic material. Non- enveloped viruses DNA RNA Parvovirus Adenovirus Polyoma virus Papovavirus (Option B) Picornavirus (Option A) Astrovirus Reovirus Calicivirus Hepatitis A Hepatitis E Enveloped viruses All other viruses except from above have an envelope, few of which are DNA RNA Pox virus (Option D) Herpes virus Hepadenovirus Deltaviridae Arena viridae Bunyaviridae Paramyxoviridae Orthomyxoviridae Filoviridae Rhabdoviridae Flaviviridae Togaviridae Matonaviridae Coronaviridae (Option C) Retroviridae Reference: Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Pages 82, 83

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient is diagnosed with a viral infection after presenting with symptoms such as fever, chills, and body aches. Laboratory analysis reveals a helical virus with a negative-sense RNA genome. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: negative-sense RNA genome. General characteristics of viruses: Virus exhibiting Helical Symmetry: (MNEMONIC: MR FAB has Corona) Rhabdoviridae Filoviridae Myxoviridae Coronaviridae Bunyaviridae Arenaviridae All other RNA viruses and DNA viruses (Except Poxviridae - Complex symmetry ) exhibit icosahedral symmetry Enveloped and Non-Enveloped virus: All other viruses have an envelope. Nucleic Acid: All DNA viruses have dsDNA except Parvoviridae All RNA viruses have a single copy of ssRNA (Unsegmented) Exception: 2 Copies of RNA: HIV dsRNA: Reoviridae Segmented: Orthomyxoviridae (7/8 segments) Reoviridae (10-12 segments) Bunyaviridae (3 segments) Arenaviridae (2 segments) Shape of viruses: Rabies virus: Bullet-shaped Ebola virus: Filamentous Poxvirus: Brick-shaped Adenovirus: Space vehicle-shaped Rotavirus: Wheel-shaped Tobacco mosaic virus: Rod-shaped Size: Largest: Poxvirus (400 nm) Smallest: Parvovirus (20 nm)

questions.question: During the production of a viral vaccine using embryonated hen’s eggs, which site is specifically utilised for the cultivation of yellow fever virus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Allantoic Sac Explanation: The Allantoic sac is the site specifically used for cultivating the yellow fever virus, providing a larger cavity for better viral yield. Isolation of Viruses: Viruses cannot be grown on artificial culture media but are cultivated through various methods, including animal inoculation, embryonated egg inoculation, or tissue cultures. Animal Inoculation: Used for the primary isolation of certain viruses, such as: Arboviruses Coxsackieviruses Both these are isolated in the brain of suckling mice. Egg Inoculation: Yolk Sac: Useful for cultivating: Arboviruses (e.g., Japanese encephalitis virus) Bacteria (e.g., Rickettsia, Chlamydia, Haemophilus ducreyi). Amniotic Sac: Used for isolating the Influenza virus Allantoic Sac: A larger cavity that provides better yields for viral vaccines , including: Influenza Yellow fever (17D) Chorioallantoic Membrane: Employed for isolating poxviruses (Eg, vaccinia and variola) & herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1, HSV-2) , which produce visible lesions known as pocks on the membrane. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 440 Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 91

questions.question: Which of the following structures can be used to cultivate the Japanese encephalitis virus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) E Explanation The Japanese encephalitis virus (an arbovirus) can be cultured using the yolk sac. Egg inoculation and the viruses associated with the specific site of inoculation: Yolk Sac: Useful for cultivating: Arboviruses (e.g., Japanese encephalitis virus) Bacteria (e.g., Rickettsia, Chlamydia, Haemophilus ducreyi). Amniotic Sac: Used for isolating the Influenza virus Allantoic Sac: Provides better yields for viral vaccines, including: Influenza Yellow fever (17D) Chorioallantoic Membrane: Employed for isolating poxviruses (Eg, vaccinia and variola) & herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1, HSV-2) , which produce visible lesions known as pocks on the membrane.

questions.question: A researcher needs to isolate a virus using a cell line that can divide a maximum of 10 to 50 times before senescence. Which of the following cell lines should they choose?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) MRC-5 Cell Line Explanation: The MRC-5 cell line is a secondary cell line that can divide 10 to 50 times before senescence. HeLa and Vero cell lines are continuous cell lines, while the chick embryo cell line has a very limited division capacity. Tissue Culture: Laboratory technique used to grow cells or tissues in a controlled environment outside their natural context. Types of Tissue Culture: Organ Culture Explant Culture Cell Line Culture Currently, Cell line cultures are the only widely used method for virus isolation. Types of Cell Lines: Primary Cell Lines Secondary/Diploid Cell Lines Continuous Cell Lines 5-10 divisions (Limited growth capacity) 10-50 divisions Indefinite growth (Continuous divisions) Maintain a diploid karyotype Maintain a diploid karyotype Altered haploid chromosomes Monkey kidney cell line (for myxoviruses, enteroviruses, adenoviruses). Human amnion cell line. Chick embryo cell line. Human fibroblast cell line (CMV) MRC-5 and WI-38 (Used for viral vaccines like rabies, chickenpox, and MMR, and virus isolation such as HSV) HeLa cell line (human cervical carcinoma) HEp-2 cell line (for RSV, adenoviruses, HSV) KB cell line (human nasopharynx carcinoma) McCoy cell line (for virus isolation and Chlamydia) Vero cell line (for rabies vaccine production). BHK cell line (baby hamster kidney). Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 441 Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 92

questions.question: A patient’s cell culture exhibits distinct cytopathic effects characterised by the formation of syncytia (multinucleated giant cells). Based on these observations, which virus is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Measles virus Explanation: Syncytia formation is a characteristic cytopathic effect associated with measles virus infection, distinguishing it from other viruses. This occurs due to the fusion of infected cells, resulting in multinucleated giant cells. While the Herpes simplex virus can also cause syncytia, measles is more characteristically associated with this effect in cell cultures. Adenovirus and enterovirus typically do not exhibit syncytia formation. Detection of Virus Growth in Cell Cultures: Cytopathic Effect (CPE) refers to the morphological changes induced by a virus in a cell line, which can be observed using a light microscope. While not all viruses cause CPE, those are known as cytopathic viruses. Each virus has a unique type of CPE that helps to identify: Enteroviruses (Option B) : Rapid CPE with cell crenation and degeneration. Measles virus: Syncytium formation (RSV or respiratory syncytial virus). Herpesvirus: Discrete focal degeneration, ballooning and syncitium formation. Adenovirus (Option A) : Large granular clumps resembling bunches of grapes. SV40 or Simian virus 40 (Option D) : Prominent cytoplasmic vacuolation. Metabolic Inhibition: Cellular metabolism produces acid in normal cultures, causing a colour change in the medium's pH indicator (phenol red). When viruses grow, metabolism gets inhibited , leading to reduced acid production and a colour change . Hemadsorption : Hemagglutinating viruses, such as influenza , can be detected by adding guinea pig erythrocytes to the culture. If the viruses replicate, the erythrocytes will adsorb onto the cell surfaces. Interference: The presence of a non-cytopathogenic virus inhibits the growth of a subsequent challenge with a known cytopathogenic virus. Transformation: Oncogenic viruses can induce cell transformation, leading to loss of contact inhibition and the formation of microtumors in culture. Other Methods for Detecting Viral Growth: Direct Immunofluorescence Assay detects viral antigens on the surface of cells. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is used to detect viral genes. Electron Microscopy allows visualisation of viruses within infected cell lines. Shell Vial Technique: For viruses like CMV , which require several weeks to exhibit CPE, the shell vial technique offers a quicker detection method (1-2 days). Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 442 Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 93

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with neurological symptoms, and a brain biopsy is performed, revealing the presence of inclusion bodies as shown in the image. What are these inclusion bodies commonly referred to as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Negri Bodies Explanation: Negri bodies are characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions found in the brain cells of animals infected with rabies, which causes neurological symptoms. Inclusion bodies : Characteristic histological features observed in virus-infected cells exhibiting distinct sizes, shapes, locations and staining properties. Types: Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies Nuclear inclusion bodies Both cytoplasmic and nuclear Inclusion bodies are generally acidophilic and appear as pink structures when stained with the Giemsa method or eosin methylene blue. Certain viruses, such as adenovirus , may produce basophilic inclusions . Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies: Negri bodies : Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions found in the brain cells of animals, indicative of rabies . Paschen body (Option A) : Variola virus Guarnieri bodies : Smaller, multiple inclusions in cells infected by vaccinia virus Bollinger bodies (Option C) : Large inclusions observed in fowlpox . Molluscum bodies (Option D) : HP bodies (Henderson Patterson Bodies) - Very large inclusion bodies (20-30 µm) found in molluscum contagiosum. questions.question: A new respiratory virus has emerged in a rural community, with early reports indicating a high transmission rate and increased hospitalisations. Public health officials must evaluate the virus's infectivity to implement effective control measures. Which of the following assays is most appropriate for quantifying the virus's infectivity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Plaque Assay Explanation: The Plaque assay is the most suitable method for quantifying viral infectivity, as it allows for the determination of the number of infectious viral particles based on the formation of plaques in a cell culture. Each plaque represents an area of localised infection caused by a single infectious unit of the virus, providing a direct count of viral infectivity. The endpoint assay (Option A) measures the highest dilution, which still produces a specific effect but does not provide a direct count. Electron microscopy (Option B) is used to visualise viral particles. Haemagglutination (Option D) detects viral activity but does not quantify it. Viral assays: Viral enumeration Electron microscopy: The ratio of a virus suspension mixed with latex particles, as observed under an electron microscope (negative staining), indicates the virus count. Hemagglutination: RBCs are added to a serial dilution of a virus sample (with H spikes) to determine the hemagglutination titer; the highest dilution showing RBC agglutination indicates the number of virions. Viral infective assays Assay Description Endpoint assay They are used for infectivity titration, for example, animal mortality, hemagglutinin production in allantoic fluid, and the appearance of cytopathic effects (CPE) in cell cultures. Plaque assay Agar is poured over a viral specimen on a cell line, revealing visible plaques (localised focus) of infected cells. The number of plaques corresponds to the infective virions. Pox assay Assessed by counting the number of pocks formed on the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) from the appropriate viral inocula (Eg, Vaccinia)

questions.question: Match the following interferons with their respective sources, 1. Alpha interferon
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b Explanation: Interferons are host-coded proteins produced in response to viral or non-viral inducers that help other cells of the same species to resist viral infections. Classification of Interferons Aspects Alpha interferon (IFN- α ) Beta interferon (IFN- β ) Gamma interferon (IFN- γ ) Structure Non-glycosylated protein Glycoprotein Glycoprotein Source Leukocytes Fibroblasts and epithelial cells Th1 (T-helper type 1) lymphocytes Function Antiviral properties Antiviral properties Used for multiple sclerosis. Immunomodulatory and anti-proliferative (granuloma formation). Treatment of chronic granulomatous disease. Chromosome (interferon) 9 9 12 Chromosome (interferon receptor) 21 21 6 Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 455.
